body.p:
1
Ladies and Gentlemen! After all that has been said
on this auspicious day, the adding of some words from my
poor vocabulary, would be,--to make use of a very inelegant
comparison--, like attempting to render a brilliant flame
still brighter by throwing therein a lucifer match. But
you are to blame for having called upon me so ill-pre-
-pared to speak fittingly and acceptably. I shall, how
-ever, screen myself from the shafts of your sharp cri-
ticism behind the [crossed-out] shield of brevity. Several of you
may perhaps be not aware that I have already spoken
at some length this morning on the subject eloquently
and liberally expounded on yonder platform, and-permit
me to say without intending any [?]dious distinction—specially
by our valued Christian friends the Honorable Horater Gates
Jones, and Mr Charles S. Sheyser. I shall not venture
therefore to repeat myself; but since I am up, and I will not
be seated without having given expression to few of the ideas
which the occasion suggested.
To you my brethren of the house of Israel I will say; that I
have seen this day illustrated again the marvellous unity of
2
of our race. Yes: we are a unit—notwithstanding
ritual differences—in whatever involves principles and
vital ideas. We are a unit in whatever pertains to
works of charity; in what concerns our inalienable rights.
We are a unit in claiming immunities warranted to all,
in defending our faith from the aspersions of ignorant
and puny-souled beings. We are a unit in loving
freedom, and in placing upon our heads as a diadem the
names of the immortal fathers of that Republic; which has
opened an asylum for the oppressed, by reason of opinion,
and has proclaimed religious liberty.
Another thought,--and I ask your pardon for being selfish--
is the circumstance that the distinguished sculptor, my honored
friend Moses Ezekiel, drew his inspiration from Italy, the
land where the bones of my parents lie, and whence I may,
with pride, tithe the land that develops poetry and artistic
genius. From Rome specially he drew that inspiration,
the Rome where our fathers dwelt from ages immemorial,
and where they disseminated lore; the Rome which
in the time of the Empire learnt what is good in Christianity
from Mosaism, as [?] records that pagans became
Judaized; the Rome of the Popes, where Israel found
a shelter to his weary feet, when expelled from barbarous
3
Spain, which does not to this day, understand the
meaning of the word Liberty; the Rome of the Popes
where our progenitors became were afterwards vilified and crashed,
caged like raveous beasts within narrow and unhealthy limits;
but now the Rome, which has, at last, fulfilled the as-
pirations of the best and greatest patriots from Dante
to Mazzini, in becoming the metropolis of regenerated
Italy. Now she has exchanged the badge of reproach
for that of honor. Now she clothes her Hebrew children
with the insignia of power, and sends them to the halls
of legislation, to teach wisdom to the country of their birth
and love & wisdom! It is my privilege, Ladies and Gentlemen!
to know some of those representative men of our race,
and I can assure you that any communities may glory
in individuals so public-spirited and liberal-hearted.
In that Rome it is then that our eminent sculptor
drew his inspiration, in sight of that Vatican, which
will yet become the possession property of its rightful owner,
Victor Emanuel, and will reveal a mine of rare knowledge
treasured therein and belonging to the sages of our people.
May Moses Ezekiel acquire in that city and in the land
which gave the world a Buonarotti and a Carnova,
renown and high celebrity, an undying name reflecting
lustre on the faith of which he is a member, and on the
country where he first saw the light of day; even the
country of Religious Liberty
Jacob Ezekiel Esqre
December 1st 1876
My dear Friend.
As you are about to leave us, I wish that you carry with you
a very trifling memento of my esteem for yourself and family, by the
accompanying speech made yesterday, and of which you expressed a
desire to possess a copy. I have endeavoured to recall it, but I am
not certain that it is exactly as delivered. The sentiments, however, are
the same, though the wording may perhaps differ. I may also have
left some of the ideas unrecorded, and have placed others in their stead,
but my head has been so full lately of literary matters, that it is
difficult to keep all in in its entirety. Reiterating my kindest
regards to your circle, and sincere prayers for your son's brilliant
success in the liberal arts, I remain
Yours very truly
S. Morais.
